body.p:
To His Excellency Thomas E Bramlette
The Governor of Kentucky

Margaret Long the Petitioner would respectfully represent to your Excellency That she resides in the City of Louisville and for some time has been very much afflicted and which affliction continues in such a way as to confine her to the house and most of the time to her bed

She states that she has no relatives living and but few friends her only brother who was her chief support before the war and who gave his life to his country in his recent Battles; for the Union being now dead and gone:
She states that at the last Term of the City Court of Louisville: on the 10th day thereof. at the Nov Term she was fined $150.0/00 for Keeping a disorderly house:

She states that she lives in a little shed of a house in an obscure part of the city and that while Gen Shermans army was here some soldiers came to her house: She did not invite them and was unable to Keep them away and a Watchman indicted her for Keeping a disorderly house therefor

She states that the neighbors never complained for they Knew the soldiers could do what they pleased: She says she is poor & sick and wholly unable to pay the fine, and She humbly prays your Excellency to remit to her the same: and will ever pray &

State of Kentucky
Jefferson County Sct
Margaret Long states that the above petition is true
Sworn to Before me on this 14 of November 1865
J. Connell J P J C
we the undersigned Citizens respectfully join in the prayer of the petitioner Margaret Long.
I am aware that ^the^ facts Set forth in the above petition are true, and would recomend the remission of Such portion of her fine as the Executive may deem prudent under the Circumstances
P. S. This woman is not worth one Hundred and fifty Dollars Visable means
